title: 9 best bedside tables to keep your alarm clock, lamp and books handy
text:
We ask a lot of this little furniture piece. A bedside table needs to be small enough to squeeze into the space between the bed and wall (often a challenge), yet we expect it to carry our lives: alarm clock, bedside lamp, reading glasses, notepad, stack of bedtime books... not to mention our morning cup o’ joe, which is why we’ve chosen these small but perfectly formed units for their style as well as all-important functionality.

With a wealth of design-led pieces around, there’s a bedside table for every homemaker. If you’re a bookworm, look for a nightstand with integrated shelving.

Some styles offer a nifty under-shelf designed to hold our pile of well-thumbed paperbacks. If minimalism’s your thing, plump for a design with deceptively spacious storage to clear the clutter – one that doesn’t interrupt the clean lines.

While some bedside tables come in a set of two, we preferred the versatility of the singular purchase because there’s often only room for one – a pertinent point if you’re a city-dweller with space at a premium.

Otherwise, you can fill your boots and invest in a matching duo of diminutive tables to suit your style, not forgetting that in the bedroom, symmetry is everything – especially if you’re going for that flawless hotel look.

Our roundup includes some affordable pieces, as well as those on the higher end of the price bracket (and double that if you’re buying a pair).

But whatever the cost, we found all of the bedside tables we tested to be both well-crafted and superbly creative in design.

You can trust our independent reviews. We may earn commission from some of the retailers, but we never allow this to influence selections, which are formed from real-world testing and expert advice. This revenue helps to fund journalism across The Independent.

Maisons du Monde sunset universe pastel yellow metal bedside table: £76, Maisons du Monde

Having a little locker by your bedside is one way to embrace industrial chic, but many are just too tall to really call themselves a nightstand – anything over 70cm and you won’t be able to easily roll over and check your phone at 4am (essential). This cute utilitarian unit had us at hello with its cheery hue and petite boxy shaping. Its epoxy finish awards it a plasticky feel – warmer than the usual cold-to-the-touch metal, and it boasts generous storage to boot.

Buy now

Tikamoon pavel acacia bedside table: £239, Tikamoon

We loved this little bedside table for its open bureau inspired design. Crafted from warming acacia wood, it brings instant Scandi calm to the bedroom whilst keeping the look clean-lined and contemporary with its black slimline legs. The natural patina of the wood adds to the unique character of this diminutive piece, and best is that it still looks great when cluttered with books and coffee-stained papers. It may be our priciest pick but we’ve fallen for this lovely little writer’s desk in miniature.

Buy now

Habitat oken sage green folding side table: £36, Habitat

Sometimes all you need is a surface, and this sweet little side table from Habitat more than does the job. As a contemporary bedside table, it is fresh, stylish and clean-lined. It’s also foldable with a removable tray top, making it a versatile piece you can easily repurpose should you need it for entertaining. We loved its subtle colour and glossy finish, as well as its unobtrusive X-shaped frame that didn’t compromise our floor space.

Buy now

Atkin & Thyme Jensen bedside drawer: £179, Atkin & Thyme

There’s industrial, and then there’s soft industrial, and the latter is far better suited to the bedroom. This single drawer on stilts is a design triumph for its simplicity, yet it manages to be utterly glamorous with its glass top and brushed bronze finish. While fully luxe on top, the bedside table has a functional, slimline angular frame in powder-coated black. The stark contrast gives the effect of a floating shelf and cleverly creates the illusion of extra space underneath.

Buy now

Oak Furnitureland Hove natural oak and painted bedside table: £189.99, Oak Furnitureland

This compact bedside cabinet is made from 100 per cent solid hardwood oak and carries a clean-lined and contemporary aesthetic. We loved its gently curved form as well as its inconspicuous recessed handles that keep the look smooth and stylish. With two generous drawers, we found we could hide all our bits and bobs away – while keeping them reassuringly close by as we snoozed. Minimal and modern, this one scored high on functionality.

Buy now

Rose & Grey left or right webbed cabinet: From £225, Rose & Grey

Thoughtful design allowed us to pick this adorable duo of bedside cabinets with left- or right-opening options. You’ll want the little brass handle closest to your side of the bed, so be sure to choose one of each if you’re ordering a pair. The hinged doors, fronted with boho-inspired cane webbing (an Eighties teen room staple), open to reveal a handy shelf for books, and while the oval shaping of the painted mango wood cabinets doesn’t allow for much on top, it will reliably hold your morning cuppa.

Buy now

Oliver Bonas iro white bedside table: £155, Oliver Bonas

We’re forever impressed with Oliver Bonas’s furniture offering and its bedside tables are no exception. Inspired by the ornate architecture of Asia, this diminutive side table manages to straddle both vintage and contemporary looks with its crisp white paintwork and decorative carving. Handcrafted from mahogany wood with brass hardware, it’s a solid furniture piece that wouldn’t look out of place in an eclectic, travel-inspired boudoir. Best is its contrasting bright turquoise tassel.

Buy now

Argos Home nomad one drawer bedside chest: £74.99, Argos Home

This cubic bedside table marries rustic charm with contemporary styling. It’s big on storage too with a deep and generous drawer, an open drawer on top of that (ideal for keeping our favourite tomes to hand), and of course a sturdy surface to place a stylish bedside lamp. The boxy look continues with an angular, modern metal frame. Part of the coordinating nomad collection, we were impressed with Argos Home’s handsome nightstand offering.

Buy now

Swoon Editions Ziggy copper bedside table: £199, Swoon

You can’t go wrong with a flash of Bowie-inspired glamour in the bedroom, which is why we loved this metallic mini cabinet as our nightstand. Intricately crafted from mango wood with a copper foil cladding, and supported by four retro hairpin legs in black, it is one seriously stylish furniture piece. And with its integrated shelf for books, bits and bobs, it’s not just a pretty facade, either. Boxy and beautiful.

Buy now

Verdict: Bedside tables

We loved Maisons du Monde’s Sunset Universe metal bedside table. It manages a rare feat of being both cute and utilitarian, and with its sunshiny shade, there’s simply no getting out of the wrong side of bed. An industrial locker style nightstand with petite proportions. We were also impressed with Rose & Grey’s duo of webbed cabinets for their thoughtful design and charmingly retro aesthetic.

IndyBest product reviews are unbiased, independent advice you can trust. On some occasions, we earn revenue if you click the links and buy the products, but we never allow this to bias our coverage. The reviews are compiled through a mix of expert opinion and real-world testing.
description: Keep all your essentials close to hand with one of these bedside tables from Argos, Oak Furnitureland, Oliver Bonas and Masisons du Monde
